page.title: Phrases from The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy

rev.comment: /* Answer to Life, the Universe, and Everything (42) */ no rationale for use
rev.diff:
Line 14: Line 14:
Lacking a real question, the mice decide not to go through the whole thing again and settle for the suggestion "How many roads must a man walk down?" from [[Bob Dylan]]'s protest song "[[Blowin' in the Wind]]".
Lacking a real question, the mice decide not to go through the whole thing again and settle for the suggestion "How many roads must a man walk down?" from [[Bob Dylan]]'s protest song "[[Blowin' in the Wind]]".
â
[[Image:Scrabble 6x9.jpg|thumb|200px|The Ultimate Question?]]
+
At the end of the first radio series (and television series, as well as ''[[The Restaurant at the End of the Universe]]'' book) [[Arthur Dent]], having escaped the Earth's destruction, potentially has some of the [[Numerical analysis#Direct and iterative methods|computational matrix]] in his brain. He attempts to discover The Ultimate Question by extracting it from his [[brainwave]] patterns, as abusively <ref name="tv6">[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (TV series)#Episode Six|Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (TV series) Episode Six]]</ref> suggested by [[Marvin the Paranoid Android]], when a [[Scrabble]]-playing caveman spells out '''forty two'''.
At the end of the first radio series (and television series, as well as ''[[The Restaurant at the End of the Universe]]'' book) [[Arthur Dent]], having escaped the Earth's destruction, potentially has some of the [[Numerical analysis#Direct and iterative methods|computational matrix]] in his brain. He attempts to discover The Ultimate Question by extracting it from his [[brainwave]] patterns, as abusively <ref name="tv6">[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (TV series)#Episode Six|Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (TV series) Episode Six]]</ref> suggested by [[Marvin the Paranoid Android]], when a [[Scrabble]]-playing caveman spells out '''forty two'''.
